hints.content:
### Key understanding

A transformation matrix on the plane has the same effect on every figure in the plane. Let's think about its effect on a unit square.

The transformation matrix $\left[\begin{array}{c}
\tealE a & \redE b
\\\\
\tealE c & \redE d
\end{array}\right]$

- maps the unit vector $\left[\begin{array}{c}
1
\\\\
0
\end{array}\right]$ to $\tealE{\left[\begin{array}{c}
a
\\\\
c
\end{array}\right]}$.

- maps the unit vector $\left[\begin{array}{c}
0
\\\\
1
\end{array}\right]$ to $\redE{\left[\begin{array}{c}
b
\\\\
d
\end{array}\right]}$.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

In our case, the transformation matrix is $\left[\begin{array}{c}
\tealE{-1} & \redE 0
\\\\
\tealE 0 & \redE 1
\end{array}\right]$.

So we need to think how the grid changes when we map $\left[\begin{array}{c}
1
\\\\
0
\end{array}\right]$ to $\tealE{\left[\begin{array}{c}
-1
\\\\
0
\end{array}\right]}$ and we map $\left[\begin{array}{c}
0
\\\\
1
\end{array}\right]$ to $\redE{\left[\begin{array}{c}
0
\\\\
1
\end{array}\right]}$.

options.explanation:
We can rewrite any vector $\left[\begin{array}{c}
x
\\\\
y
\end{array}\right]$ as $x\cdot\left[\begin{array}{c}
1
\\\\
0
\end{array}\right]+y\cdot\left[\begin{array}{c}
0
\\\\
1
\end{array}\right]$. So the effect of the transformation on the unit vectors tells us how the transformation affects *any* vector.
options.showPrompt: Why does this tell us the transformation of every figure in the plane?

hints.content:
Notice that under this transformation, the vertical unit vectors stays put while the horizontal unit vector switches sides:

[[☃ image 1]]

So any vector whose coordinates were $\left[\begin{array}{c}
x
\\\\
y
\end{array}\right]$ is now at $\left[\begin{array}{c}
-x
\\\\
y
\end{array}\right]$.

Which geometric transformation has that effect?

A reflection across $y$-axis has that effect:

[[☃ image 1]]
The transformation is a reflection across the $y$-axis.

question.content:
Consider this matrix transformation:

$\left[\begin{array}{c}
-1 & 0
\\\\
0 & 1
\end{array}\right]$

**What is the geometric effect of this transformation?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: A reflection across the $y$-axis
A reflection across the line $y=x$
A rotation about the origin by $90\degree$
A rotation about the origin by $180\degree$

hints.content:
### Key understanding

The absolute value of a transformation matrix's determinant gives us the area of the unit square's image under the transformation.

[[☃ explanation 2]]

As a result, the ratio between the area of any image and the area of its pre-image is equal to the absolute value of the determinant:

$\dfrac{\text{area of image}}{\text{area of pre-image}}=\text{absolute value of determinant}$

[[☃ explanation 1]]

We can use the given information to substitute some values into this equation and then find the area of the image.

options.explanation:
Let's consider a general matrix transformation $\bold A$.

We can view the transformation as if it's distorting the grid itself. So if we were able to fit $S$ unit squares within a figure before the transformation, we are going to be able to fit $S$ images of the unit square in the image of the figure.

Since the image of the unit square is going to have an area equal to $|\det(\bold A)|$, the area of the image of the figure is going to be $S\cdot |\det(\bold A)|$.
options.showPrompt: Why is this true?

options.explanation:
We know that the transformation matrix $\left[\begin{array}{c}
\tealE a & \redE b
\\\\
\tealE c & \redE d
\end{array}\right]$ maps the unit vector $\left[\begin{array}{c}
1
\\\\
0
\end{array}\right]$ to $\tealE{\left[\begin{array}{c}
a
\\\\
c
\end{array}\right]}$ and maps the unit vector $\left[\begin{array}{c}
0
\\\\
1
\end{array}\right]$ to $\redE{\left[\begin{array}{c}
b
\\\\
d
\end{array}\right]}$.

Here is a drawing of the image of the unit square, in the case where $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$ are all positive:

[[☃ image 1]]

You can see how the image (which is a parallelogram) is enclosed by a rectangle whose area is $(a+b)(c+d)$, and that the rest of the rectangle consists of smaller rectangles and right triangles whose total area is $2bc+bd+ac$. So this is the area of the image:

$\begin{align}
&\phantom{=} (a+b)(c+d)-(2bc+bd+ac)
\\\\
&=ac+ad+bc+bd-2bc-bd-ac
\\\\
&=ad-bc
\end{align}$

And $ad-bc$ is indeed the determinant of the matrix! Note that this calculation is different in the cases where some of the matrix's elements are negative (or zero), but the result will always be that the area is equal to $|ad-bc|$.
options.showPrompt: Why is this true?

hints.content:
The area of the rectangle is $5\times 8=40$ square units:

[[☃ image 1]]

Now let's find the absolute value of the determinant of the matrix:

$\begin{align}
&\phantom{=}\left|\det\left(\left[\begin{array}{c}
-7 & 8
\\\\
-5 & 9
\end{array}\right]\right)\right|
\\\\
&=|-7\cdot 9-8\cdot (-5)|
\\\\
&=|-23|
\\\\
&=23
\end{align}$

As we said above, the ratio between the area of the image and the area of the pre-image is equal to the absolute value of the determinant:

$\begin{align}
\dfrac{\text{area of image}}{40}&=23
\\\\
\text{area of image}&=920
\end{align}$
The area of the image of the rectangle under the transformation is $920$ square units.
